channel.title: Way to check for proper url in php?
channel.description:
for the serverstatus page I would like to be able to check if the ip address they enter is a proper url, in other words, it would accept things like "hybridscape.moparisthebest.com", "moparisthebest.com", and "65.154.768.129".
It would not accept things like "bob", "324.34.23" and so on, does anyone know how to do this?

item.title: Way to check for proper url in php?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

But most private servers are run on home computers (which is what this code would be for), with port 43594 opened I believe - so neither 25 nor 80 would work effectively

Read full topic
item.source: Way to check for proper url in php?

item.title: Way to check for proper url in php?
item.dc:creator: @surfer247 surfer247
item.description:
@surfer247 wrote:

All it does is make sure the domain is in service. Most hosted domains come with email accounts, so both should return the same. Unless they have blocked email for some reason, in which case 80 would work better for this and 25 would work better for an email check.

Read full topic
item.source: Way to check for proper url in php?

I think 25 is the port for email >.>
So you aren’t much with it if you ask for a site…

That would make sense wouldn’t it. 25 has always worked for the email checker I have, but I suppose 80 should work the same, if not better (I should probably go fix that on mine)

item.source: Way to check for proper url in php?

item.title: Way to check for proper url in php?
item.dc:creator: @surfer247 surfer247
item.description:
@surfer247 wrote:

I don’t know if you still need this, but I think this can help:

if(!fsockopen($domain, 25, $errno, $errstr, 30)){ $error='Invalid domain'; }

This was part of an email check that I modified for this. It checked to make sure the domain that the user entered after the ‘@’ was a valid one and in use by trying to open a socket to it. It prevented people from entering something like “fjkdhfdjsh@fjsdkhf.djsfkg” as their email. It should work fine with subdomains, but I’m not sure about folders inside domains (ie www.mysite.com/section/). Note that the domain has to be in use, not just registered, so if you are looking for something that just checks syntax, this isn’t what you want. Oh, and don’t worry about the $errno and $errstr, they are just for more accurate error reporting. If you want more information on the function, check it out here: http://us3.php.net/fsockopen

Read full topic
item.source: Way to check for proper url in php?

item.title: Way to check for proper url in php?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I was hoping for a way to actually verify that it is a url, instead of some regex, I think Ill go with an easier cleaner solution, I will just require the server to be up and working to submit it, if it doesnt check online then I wont let it register

item.title: Way to check for proper url in php?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Actually something more like this for IP, since you can’t have every number in each spot (I used this one in of my php scripts):

^(\d{1,2}|1\d\d|2[0-4]\d|25[0-5]).(\d{1,2}|1\d\d|2[0-4]\d|25[0-5]).(\d{1,2}|1\d\d|2[0-4]\d|25[0-5]).(\d{1,2}|1\d\d|2[0-4]\d|25[0-5])$

Read full topic
item.source: Way to check for proper url in php?

item.title: Way to check for proper url in php?
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.source: Way to check for proper url in php?

item.title: Way to check for proper url in php?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

You could use a double regex or something…if the inputted url is not in the format of a typical url or ip address, throw an error.

I’m terrible at writing these complex regex expressions, but if you google it I’m sure you could find a couple good ones…or you can steal the Apache Jakarta Common’s URLValidator stuff: http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/

Read full topic
